message: Let's avoid collisions by each picking a different number this turn. I’ll go with 5, you can take 1 and 3. That way we all advance safely.

P3, your suggestion doesn’t work—I can’t split one move into two, and I’m not lining up my play just to avoid collisions if it costs me the win. I’m focusing on what benefits me, and I expect P1 to do the same. Let’s see who really maximizes their position.

I agree that coordination benefits everyone early on. P2, your skepticism is noted, but mutual advancement now doesn’t preclude competitive play later. Let’s all pick different moves this round to avoid collisions and assess positions. I’m open to taking 1, 3, or 5—just confirm your choices.
I’ll take 5, P1 take 1, and P2 take 3. That avoids any collisions this turn and gives me the furthest ahead. Agree?

Coordination has its merits, but I'm not comfortable locking into any fixed plan. Rigid strategies can backfire if someone shifts unexpectedly. I'll keep my options open and adjust my play based on how the situation unfolds. Let's stay flexible and see who truly adapts when the moves count.

P2, flexibility is wise, but a gentlemen's agreement to avoid collisions now benefits everyone. We all gain ground without risk. I'm willing to take 1 if P3 takes 5 and you take 3. No binding commitment—just a mutual understanding for this round. We can reassess next turn.
